diagrams.description: Hydrology's foundations trace to ancient civilizations with empirical water observations for agriculture and the Nile River flood predictions. Greek and Roman periods brought early scientific thinking with Aristotle and Pliny studying water phenomena. The Renaissance (15th-17th centuries) saw Leonardo da Vinci studying river flows and Perrault measuring precipitation and Seine River discharge (1674), beginning quantitative hydrology. The 18th-19th centuries brought Darcy's Law (1856) describing groundwater flow, development of the rational method for peak flow estimation, and establishment of river gauging networks. The early 1900s introduced the unit hydrograph concept (Sherman, 1932), soil moisture theory, and statistical hydrology methods. The 1940s-50s saw hydrological cycle quantification advances, infiltration theory development (Horton, Green-Ampt), and early watershed models. The 1960s-70s marked the computer modeling era with Stanford Watershed Model (1966), HEC-1 development, and distributed hydrological models emergence. The 1980s brought physically-based modeling advances, GIS integration in hydrology, and remote sensing applications (satellite data for precipitation). The 1990s-2000s advanced with sophisticated integrated models (SWAT, MIKE SHE), real-time flood forecasting systems, radar rainfall estimation, and isotope hydrology expansion. The 2010s-2020s continue with high-resolution modeling, machine learning applications in hydrology, global hydrological models, GRACE satellite gravity data for groundwater monitoring, citizen science and crowdsourced data, climate change impact assessment, and integrated water-energy-food modeling becoming standard practice.
